commit.message:
Add tail-call semantics to script interpreter (not active).

If, at the end of script execution, the stack has more than one item on it, the top-most element is interpreted as a serialized script and executed, with the remaining elements on the stack as inputs. No state is maintained, and termination of the subscript terminates execution of the script as a whole. Only one tail-call is allowed per script execution, and neither P2SH nor segwit nor execution of the scriptSig results in tail-call semantics, although the P2SH or segwit redeem script can make a single tail-call.

verification.payload:

author Mark Friedenbach <mark@friedenbach.org> 1504139855 -0700
committer Karl-Johan Alm <karljohan-alm@garage.co.jp> 1524550269 +0900

Add tail-call semantics to script interpreter (not active).

If, at the end of script execution, the stack has more than one item on it, the top-most element is interpreted as a serialized script and executed, with the remaining elements on the stack as inputs. No state is maintained, and termination of the subscript terminates execution of the script as a whole. Only one tail-call is allowed per script execution, and neither P2SH nor segwit nor execution of the scriptSig results in tail-call semantics, although the P2SH or segwit redeem script can make a single tail-call.

commit.message: Enable tail-call semantics as a standard script validation flag. Transactions that fail tail-call verification will be rejected from the mempool, making it easier to test and later soft-fork activate this feature. Blocks which contain transactions with "invalid" tail-call semantics will still be accepted; this is *not* the soft-fork required to use tail-call semantics in production.

verification.payload:
tree c66c13ebf10798a77ba3e5e7dc1803931dfffd0c
parent c21fb91adeeb64100e126b2a388966c1a3aacad3
author Mark Friedenbach <mark@friedenbach.org> 1504140265 -0700
committer Karl-Johan Alm <karljohan-alm@garage.co.jp> 1524550269 +0900

Enable tail-call semantics as a standard script validation flag. Transactions that fail tail-call verification will be rejected from the mempool, making it easier to test and later soft-fork activate this feature. Blocks which contain transactions with "invalid" tail-call semantics will still be accepted; this is *not* the soft-fork required to use tail-call semantics in production.
